qas.question: What is the group of animals that often have a specialized head with feeding and sensory organs called?
How many openings in the digestive chamber do animals in the Bilateria group have?
What are the openings in the digestive chambers for animals in the Bilateria group called?
What is the internal body cavity of animals in the Bilateria group called?

context: The remaining animals form a monophyletic group called the <a0_0>Bilateria<a0_0/>. For the most part, they are bilaterally symmetric, and often have a specialized head with feeding and sensory organs. The body is triploblastic, i.e. all three germ layers are well-developed, and tissues form distinct organs. The digestive chamber has <a1_0>two<a1_0/> openings, a <a2_0>mouth and an anus<a2_0/>, and there is also an internal body cavity called a <a3_0>coelom or pseudocoelom<a3_0/>. There are exceptions to each of these characteristics, however — for instance adult echinoderms are radially symmetric, and certain parasitic worms have extremely simplified body structures.
